questions.text: Read the passage: 'Maria stared at the trophy, remembering how she almost gave up during the race.' What quote from the text shows Maria's internal struggle?

choices: remembering how she almost gave up
questionOptions.correctAnswer: remembering how she almost gave up

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: When quoting from a text to support your answer, you should use the exact words from the passage.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What is the theme of a story?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: The central message or lesson

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: A story about a boy who learns to be honest after lying has the theme 'Honesty is the best policy.'
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Which type of conflict involves a character struggling against their own fears or doubts?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: Character vs. Self

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Match each theme to the story that best represents it.

rightItems: A girl practices piano daily and wins the competition
Two friends work together to solve a mystery
A soldier saves his village despite his fear
A boy refuses to change who he is to fit in

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: How are a protagonist and an antagonist different?

choices: The protagonist is the main character; the antagonist opposes them
The protagonist is always good; the antagonist is always evil
The protagonist appears first; the antagonist appears last
There is no difference between them
questionOptions.correctAnswer: The protagonist is the main character; the antagonist opposes them

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Which best describes a 'static' character?

choices: A character who changes throughout the story
A character who stays the same throughout the story
A character who appears in flashbacks
A character who narrates the story
questionOptions.correctAnswer: A character who stays the same throughout the story

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Match each character type to its description.

rightItems: Changes or grows during the story
Has few traits and is simple
Stays the same throughout
Has many traits and is complex

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: A setting can influence a character's mood and actions in a story.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What does the phrase 'walking on thin ice' mean in figurative language?

choices: Being in a risky or dangerous situation
questionOptions.correctAnswer: Being in a risky or dangerous situation

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: A metaphor directly compares two things without using 'like' or 'as'.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Match each literary device to its definition.

rightItems: Extreme exaggeration
Comparison using like/as
Giving human traits to non-human things
Direct comparison without like/as

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Which sentence contains an example of personification?

choices: The boy ran as fast as a cheetah.
The wind whispered through the trees.
questionOptions.correctAnswer: The wind whispered through the trees.

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What is the main purpose of a story's climax?

choices: To present the turning point of the story
questionOptions.correctAnswer: To present the turning point of the story

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Foreshadowing gives hints about what will happen later in the story.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Put the story elements in the correct sequence.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: A flashback shows events that happened in the past.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: The resolution is the part of the story where the conflict is solved.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Read the passage: 'James said, "I will never give up on my dream."' Which quote from the text shows James's determination?

choices: I will never give up on my dream
questionOptions.correctAnswer: I will never give up on my dream

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: When you paraphrase, you use the exact words from the text.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Which is the best way to support an inference about a character?

choices: Use only pictures from the story
Ask a friend what they think
questionOptions.correctAnswer: Quote directly from the text

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Match the text evidence type to its description.

rightItems: A logical conclusion based on clues
Exact words from the text in quotation marks
Restating ideas in your own words
Brief overview of main ideas

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: A good summary includes only the most important events and details.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What should NOT be included in a summary of a story?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: Your personal opinions

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Arrange the steps for summarizing a story in the correct order.

draggableItems: Write the summary in your own words
Identify the main characters and setting
Determine how the conflict is resolved

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: When comparing two characters, you look for ways they are alike.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Which best describes how setting can affect a story's events?

choices: Setting has no effect on events
A desert setting might create challenges with finding water
questionOptions.correctAnswer: A desert setting might create challenges with finding water

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: In the sentence 'The classroom was a zoo,' what type of figurative language is used?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: Metaphor

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What does the idiom 'break a leg' mean?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: Good luck

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Match each figurative phrase to its meaning.

rightItems: Go to sleep
Raining very hard
Very easy
Reveal a secret

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: An alliteration is when words close together start with the same sound.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What is the purpose of a stanza in a poem?

choices: To group related lines together like a paragraph
questionOptions.correctAnswer: To group related lines together like a paragraph

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: How do chapters help organize a novel?

choices: They make the book more expensive
They divide the story into manageable sections with related events
They are only used in short stories
questionOptions.correctAnswer: They divide the story into manageable sections with related events

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Arrange these drama elements in the order they typically appear in a play.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: A scene in a play is similar to a chapter in a novel.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Match the text structure to the type of writing.

rightItems: Poems
Novels
Plays - large sections
Plays - smaller sections

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Which sentence contains a simile?

choices: The stars danced in the sky.
questionOptions.correctAnswer: Her smile was like sunshine.

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Read: 'Sarah looked at her old teddy bear and remembered her grandmother.' What can you infer about the teddy bear?

choices: It probably came from her grandmother
questionOptions.correctAnswer: It probably came from her grandmother

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What is the best theme for a story where a character helps others and receives help in return?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: Kindness is rewarded

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Arrange the elements to show how a character might develop through a story.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What does 'time flew by' mean?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: Time passed quickly

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: When contrasting two settings, you look for ways they are different.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: How can a reader determine the theme of a story?

choices: By looking at what characters learn and how they change
By counting the number of pages
By reading the first sentence only
questionOptions.correctAnswer: By looking at what characters learn and how they change

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Match the context clue type to its example.

rightItems: The dog was not mean; it was friendly.
Mammals, such as dogs and cats, are warm-blooded.
The happy, joyful children played outside.
A habitat is a place where an animal lives.

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Why might an author use a cliffhanger at the end of a chapter?

choices: To make readers want to keep reading
questionOptions.correctAnswer: To make readers want to keep reading

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Which quote would best support the idea that a character is brave?

choices: 'Despite her fear, she stepped forward to help.'
questionOptions.correctAnswer: 'Despite her fear, she stepped forward to help.'

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Arrange these steps for using text evidence correctly.

draggableItems: Explain how the quote supports your answer
Find a relevant quote from the text

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: An onomatopoeia is a word that imitates a sound.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Which is an example of onomatopoeia?

choices: She is as tall as a tree
questionOptions.correctAnswer: Buzz went the bee

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What is the narrator's role in a story?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: To tell the story

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: First-person point of view uses words like 'I' and 'me'.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Which point of view uses 'he,' 'she,' and 'they' to tell the story?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: Third person

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Match each point of view to its description.

rightItems: Narrator knows all characters' thoughts
Narrator tells own story using 'I'
Narrator knows one character's thoughts

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Read: 'The old house creaked and groaned as if telling its secrets.' What literary device is used?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: Personification

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: A story's mood is the feeling it creates in the reader.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Which word best describes the mood created by a dark, stormy setting?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: Suspenseful

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Arrange these events from a typical story in order.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: The tone of a story reflects the author's attitude toward the subject.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What is the difference between mood and tone?

choices: Mood is the reader's feeling; tone is the author's attitude
Tone is the reader's feeling; mood is the author's attitude
questionOptions.correctAnswer: Mood is the reader's feeling; tone is the author's attitude

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Match each mood word to its matching setting.

rightItems: A haunted mansion at midnight
A sunny park with children playing
A foggy forest with strange sounds
A quiet meadow with flowers blooming

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Read: 'Tom had waited a million years for this moment.' What literary device is used?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: Hyperbole

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: A character's motivation is the reason behind their actions.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What motivates a character who studies hard to get into a good college?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: Desire for success

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Which sentence shows indirect characterization?

choices: Maya shared her lunch with the new student.
The author described Maya as generous.
Maya is the nicest person in class.
questionOptions.correctAnswer: Maya shared her lunch with the new student.

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Match each type of characterization to its example.

rightItems: He wondered if he could ever be brave enough.
The narrator says 'She was clever.'
She quickly finished the puzzle before anyone else.
'I promise I'll help you,' she said.

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: External conflict occurs within a character's mind.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Which is an example of external conflict?

choices: A boy feeling nervous about a test
Two friends arguing about a game
A girl wondering what to wear
A character thinking about the future
questionOptions.correctAnswer: Two friends arguing about a game

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Arrange these conflict types from internal to external.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What does it mean to make an inference while reading?

choices: To use clues to figure out something not directly stated
questionOptions.correctAnswer: To use clues to figure out something not directly stated

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: A poem with an ABAB rhyme scheme has the first and third lines rhyme.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What is rhythm in poetry?

choices: The rhyming words at the end of lines
The pattern of stressed and unstressed syllables
questionOptions.correctAnswer: The pattern of stressed and unstressed syllables

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Match each poetic term to its definition.

rightItems: A single line of poetry
Sound patterns at end of words
A group of lines in a poem
Pattern of beats in poetry

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Read: 'Sally sells seashells by the seashore.' This is an example of what literary device?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: Alliteration

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Imagery helps readers visualize what is happening in a story.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Which sentence contains imagery appealing to the sense of smell?

choices: The fresh bread's aroma filled the kitchen.
The sunset was orange and pink.
questionOptions.correctAnswer: The fresh bread's aroma filled the kitchen.

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Match each type of imagery to its example.

rightItems: The smoke smelled of burning wood.
The bright red roses bloomed.
The thunder rumbled loudly.
The ice felt cold and slippery.

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What is the purpose of a prologue in a story?

choices: To provide background information before the main story
questionOptions.correctAnswer: To provide background information before the main story

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: An epilogue comes at the end of a story and tells what happens after the main events.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Which best describes a myth?

choices: A true story about recent events
A traditional story explaining natural phenomena or beliefs
A biography of a famous person
questionOptions.correctAnswer: A traditional story explaining natural phenomena or beliefs

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Arrange these narrative techniques in order from providing most to least reader access to characters' thoughts.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: A legend is a traditional story that may be based on real people or events.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What is a fable?

choices: A short story with animals that teaches a moral lesson
questionOptions.correctAnswer: A short story with animals that teaches a moral lesson

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Match each genre to its typical characteristic.

rightItems: May include larger-than-life heroes
Often explains how something in nature came to be
Features talking animals with a moral
Passed down through generations in a culture

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of dramatic irony?

choices: A character says they hate surprises and then gets a surprise party
The reader knows the villain is hiding, but the hero does not
A character says 'Nice weather!' during a storm
questionOptions.correctAnswer: The reader knows the villain is hiding, but the hero does not

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Symbolism is when an object represents something beyond its literal meaning.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: In many stories, what might a dove symbolize?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: Peace

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Match each symbol to what it commonly represents.

rightItems: Connection or transition
Love
Knowledge or hope
Conflict or trouble

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What is the primary difference between fiction and nonfiction?

choices: Fiction is imaginary; nonfiction is factual
Nonfiction has characters; fiction does not
questionOptions.correctAnswer: Fiction is imaginary; nonfiction is factual

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Historical fiction takes place during a real time period in history but has fictional characters or events.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Arrange these steps for analyzing how two characters respond differently to the same event.

draggableItems: Explain what causes the different responses
Identify the event both characters experience

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What does the phrase 'a blessing in disguise' mean?

choices: Something bad that turns out to be good
questionOptions.correctAnswer: Something bad that turns out to be good

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: The setting of a story only includes the physical location.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Which elements make up a story's setting?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: Time, place, and social environment

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: When an author writes that a character's hands trembled, what does this suggest about the character?

choices: The character is nervous or afraid
questionOptions.correctAnswer: The character is nervous or afraid

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: A story can have more than one theme.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: What is the function of dialogue in a story?

choices: To reveal character and advance the plot
questionOptions.correctAnswer: To reveal character and advance the plot

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Match each author's purpose to its example.

rightItems: A diary entry about a sad day
An adventure story about pirates
A speech about why to recycle
An article explaining how volcanoes work

questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: When comparing stories from different cultures, readers look for common themes and unique cultural elements.
questions.subject: Reading

questions.text: Which best describes how readers can compare and contrast stories in the same genre?

choices: By counting the number of pages
By examining themes, characters, settings, and plot structures
By looking only at the covers
By reading only the first chapter
questionOptions.correctAnswer: By examining themes, characters, settings, and plot structures

questions.subject: Reading
